font-size:smaller;"| *[[Phi Alpha - Local]] 1948 (Became Phi Sigma Delta in 1959) *[[Phi Beta Sigma]] 1972 *[[Phi Chi Theta]] *[[Phi Gamma Delta]] 1979 *[[Phi Gamma Nu]] 2009 *[[Phi Delta Sigma]] fraternity 2007 *[[Phi Delta Theta]] 1930 *[[Phi Iota Alpha]] 2000 (Closed) *[[Phi Kappa Tau]] 1950 *[[Phi Kappa Psi]] 2007 *[[Phi Kappa Sigma]] 1899 (closed 1995) *[[Phi Sigma Delta]] 1948 (Became Zeta Beta Tau in 1990) *[[Phi Sigma Kappa]] 1897 (closed 2002, rechartered 2011) *[[Pi Delta Psi]] 2004 (closed 2009) *[[Pi Kappa Alpha]] (closed 2011) *[[Pi Kappa Phi]] 1992 (closed 2003) *[[Sigma Alpha Epsilon]] 1943 (rechartered 2009) *[[Sigma Alpha Mu]] 1933 (closed 2011) *[[Sigma Beta Rho]] 2003 (unrecognized 2010) *[[Sigma Chi]] 1945 (rechartered 2009) *[[Sigma Nu]] 1917 *[[Sigma Pi]] (recolonized 2007) (closed 2009) *[[Sigma Phi Delta]] 2012 *[[Sigma Phi Epsilon]] 1949 *[[Sigma Phi Sigma]] 1916 local (closed) *[[Tau Epsilon Phi]] 1925 (closed 2010, recolonized 2014) *[[Tau Kappa Epsilon]] 1947 (recolonized 2005, closed 2016) *[[Theta Chi]] 1929 *[[Zeta Beta Tau]] 1948 (as Phi Sigma Delta, closed 2009, recolonized 2014) *[[Zeta Psi]] 1976 |} ==Athletics== {{main article|Maryland Terrapins}} [[File:Comcast Center interior.jpg|thumb|[[XFINITY Center (College Park, Maryland)|XFINITY Center]], home of Maryland basketball]]The university sponsors varsity athletic teams in 20 men's and women's sports. The teams, named the "Terrapins", represent Maryland in [[National Collegiate Athletic Association]] [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I]] competition. Maryland became a founding member of the [[Atlantic Coast Conference]] in 1952, but left to join the [[Big Ten Conference]] July 1, 2014. As of April 2015, Maryland's athletic teams have been awarded 42 national championships by the NCAA, [[United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association|USILA]], [[Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women|AIAW]], and [[National Cheerleaders Association|NCA]].{{cite web|url=http://www.umterps.com/genrel/md-national-championships.html |title=National Championships |publisher=Umterps.com |date= |accessdate=April 23, 2012}} In 2008 and 2010, ''[[The Princeton Review]]'' named the University of Maryland's athletic facilities the best in the nation.[http://www.bizjournals.com/baltimore/stories/2008/07/28/daily36.html Maryland colleges get high and low marks on Princeton Review study], ''Baltimore Business Journal'', August 1, 2008. Retrieved June 16, 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.princetonreview.com/best-press-release.aspx |title=Best Colleges Press Release |publisher=Princetonreview.com |date=August 1, 2011 |accessdate=April 23, 2012}} The Terrapins nickname (often shortened to "Terps") was coined by former university president, football coach, and athletic director [[Curly Byrd|H. C. "Curly" Byrd]] in 1932.{{cite web| last = CollegeFootballHistory.com | title = Maryland Terrapins History – College Football| accessdate =July 9, 2010| url = http://www.collegefootballhistory.com/maryland/history.htm}} The mascot is a [[diamondback terrapin]] named ''Testudo'', which is [[Latin]] for "tortoise."{{cite web|url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/testudo |title=Testudo |publisher=Merriam-webster.com |date= |accessdate=April 23, 2012}} Since the early 20th century, the school athletic colors have been some combination of those on the [[Flag of Maryland|Maryland state flag]]: red, white, black, and gold.{{cite web |url=http://www.umterps.com/school-bio/md-school-colors.html |title=School Colors |publisher=Umterps.com |accessdate=April 23, 2012}} [[File:Chevy Chase Field at Byrd Stadium 9-13-08.jpg|thumb|right|[[Maryland Stadium]] on game day]] [[Maryland Terrapins men's basketball|Men's basketball]] is one of the most popular sports at the university. Long-time head coach [[Lefty Driesell]] began the now nationwide tradition of "[[Midnight Madness (basketball)|Midnight Madness]] in 1971.{{Cite news | last = Landman| first = Brian| title = Sports: He made midnight a time for madness| work = St. Petersburg Times| accessdate =June 18, 2010| date = October 13, 2006 | url = http://www.sptimes.com/2006/10/13/Sports/He_made_midnight_a_ti.shtml}} Beginning in 1989, alumnus [[Gary Williams]] revived the program, which was struggling in the wake of [[Len Bias]]'s death and NCAA rules infractions. Williams led Maryland basketball to national prominence with two [[NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|Final Four]] appearances, and in 2002, a [[2002 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|national championship]]. On February 7, 2006, Gary Williams won his 349th game to surpass Driesell and became Maryland's all-time leader among basketball coaches. In May 2011 Williams retired allowing for the entrance of new head coach, Mark Turgeon. The court at XFINITY Center at the UMD was named in honor of the dearly beloved coach, Gary Williams. [[Maryland Terrapins football|Maryland football]] is also popular at the university.[https://books.google.com/books?id=fD81Hmy1tcQC ''University of Maryland College Prowler Off the Record''], p. 84–86, 2005, ISBN 1-59658-160-3. The Terrapins were awarded the national championship by the wire services in 1953, and in 1951, by several retroactive selectors. Beyond the two "revenue sports," the university fields 18 other varsity teams. The [[Maryland Terrapins women's basketball|women's basketball team]] rose to prominence in the 2000s (decade), and head coach [[Brenda Frese]] guided the Lady Terps to their first NCAA title in 2006.{{cite web|url=http://www.umterps.com/sports/w-baskbl/recaps/030809aaa.html |title=Maryland Athletics – University of Maryland Official Athletic Site – Women's Basketball |publisher=Umterps.com |date=March 8, 2009 |accessdate=May 8, 2010}} [[File:D1 Lacrosse.jpg|thumb|right|[[Maryland Terrapins men's lacrosse|Maryland]] fields one of the nation's premier [[field lacrosse|lacrosse]] programs.]][[Maryland Terrapins men's lacrosse|Maryland men's lacrosse]] remains one of the sport's top programs since its beginnings as a squad in 1865,{{Cite book| publisher = Weigl Publishers| isbn = 978-1-59036-000-2 | page = 26| last = Craats| first = Rennay| title = Maryland| location = Mankato, Minnesota| year = 2002}} although it last won the national championship in [[1975 NCAA Division I Men's Lacrosse Championship|1975]]. The team has won ten [[United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association|USILA]] and NCAA national championships since its promotion to varsity status in 1924 and is a regular fixture in the [[NCAA Division I Men's Lacrosse Championship|NCAA tournament]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ncaa.com/history/m-lacrosse-d1.html|title=The Official Website of NCAA Championships – History|publisher=NCAA.com|accessdate=May 8, 2010}} The [[Maryland Terrapins women's lacrosse|women's lacrosse team]] has the most national championships of any program in the nation, including most recently in 2014.{{cite web|title=Women's Lacrosse: Maryland captures first NCAA title since 2001 with 13–11 win over Northwestern|accessdate=June 18, 2010 | date = May 30, 2010| url = http://insidelacrosse.com/news/2010/05/30/womens-lacrosse-maryland-captures-first-ncaa-title-2001-with-13-11-win-over}} The [[Maryland Terrapins men's soccer|men' soccer team]] has reached six Final Fours since 1997 under the guidance of head coach [[Sasho Cirovski]] and captured the [[NCAA Division I Men's Soccer Championship|College Cup]] in 2005 and 2008. The soccer team has developed a large, devoted fan base among students and the local community. The attendance record at Ludwig Field was set in 2008 when 6,500 spectators saw MD take on Wake Forest. The annual total attendance has increased dramatically from 12,710 in 1995 to 35,631 in 2008.{{cite web | title = Maryland Men's Soccer: NCAA Tournament History| accessdate =December 6, 2010| url = http://www.umterps.com/sports/m-soccer/history/ncaa_history.html}} The women's [[field hockey]] team has won seven NCAA championships.{{cite web| title = Maryland Field Hockey: 2010 National Champions| accessdate =December 6, 2010 | date = November 22, 2010| url = http://www.umterps.com/sports/w-fieldh/2010_champions/}} The [[Mighty Sound of Maryland]] marching band attends all home football games and provides pre-game performances.{{cite web |url=http://www.music.umd.edu/ensembles/bands/marching_band |title="Mighty Sound of Maryland" Marching Band|publisher=Music.umd.edu|accessdate=April 23, 2012}} During the basketball season, the marching band becomes the University of Maryland Pep Band, which provides music in the stands at men's and women's home games and during tournament play.{{cite web |url=http://www.music.umd.edu/ensembles/bands/basketball_pep_band |title=Basketball Pep Band |publisher=Music.umd.edu |accessdate=April 23, 2012}} On July 1, 2012, the university cut seven varsity teams: men's cross country, men's indoor track, men's swimming and diving, men's tennis, women's acrobatics and tumbling, women's swimming and diving, and women's water polo. The men's outdoor track team had been scheduled to be cut, but the team raised $888,000 of a target amount of $940,000, sufficient to avoid elimination.{{cite web|url=http://tracking.si.com/2012/07/03/university-of-maryland-cuts-sports-teams/|title=University of Maryland cuts 7 sports teams, saves men's outdoor track |publisher=si.com |accessdate=October 5, 2012}} ==Testudo== [[File:UMD Testudo Statue.JPG|thumb|Statue of Testudo on campus]] In 1932, [[Curley Byrd]]—who served as the university's football and baseball coach, athletic director, and president—proposed adopting the [[diamondback terrapin]] as a mascot. The first statue of Testudo cast in bronze was donated by the Class of 1933 and displayed on [[U.S. Route 1 in Maryland|Baltimore Avenue]] in front of [[Ritchie Coliseum]]. However, the 300-pound sculpture was subjected to vandalism by visiting college athletic teams.{{cite web|url=http://www.umterps.com/trads/md-m-fb-mas.html |title=Testudo: Tale of the Top Shell |publisher=Umterps.com |date=May 23, 1933 |accessdate=April 23, 2012}} [[Johns Hopkins – Maryland rivalry#Early years|One such incident]] occurred in 1947 when students from [[Johns Hopkins University]] stole the bronze statue and moved it to their campus. Maryland students traveled to [[Baltimore]] to retrieve it, laying siege to the house where it was hidden. Over 200 [[Baltimore Police Department|city police]] responded to quell the riot.{{Cite news| last = Lee| first = Edward| title = Catalino, Reed lead No. 5 Terps past No. 20 Mids – Baltimore Sun| work = Baltimore Sun | location = College Park, Md.| accessdate =June 18, 2010| date = April 11, 2010| url = http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2010-04-11/sports/bal-sp.terpslax11apr11_1_grant-catalino-midshipmen-terps-sophomore-attackman}} In 1949, University President Byrd was awakened by a phone call from a [[University of Virginia]] fraternity requesting that Testudo be removed from their lawn. Testudo was later filled with 700 pounds of cement and fastened to his pedestal to prevent future removals, but students at rival schools continued to vandalize it. It was moved to [[Maryland Stadium]] in 1951. In the 1960s, Testudo was moved back to a spot in front of McKeldin Library.{{cite web|url=http://www.umd.edu/traditions/testudo/ |title=Traditions at The University of Maryland |publisher=Umd.edu |date=May 23, 1933 |accessdate=June 26, 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.umd.edu/traditions/landmarks/ |title=Traditions at The University of Maryland |publisher=Umd.edu |date=September 24, 2003 |accessdate=June 26, 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.lib.umd.edu/univarchives/macmil/testudo.html |title=Mac To Millennium: Testudo |publisher=Lib.umd.edu |accessdate=June 26, 2010}}{{Cite news| last = Rasmussen| first = Frederick| title = A stroke of good luck in Terps sculpture – Baltimore Sun| work = Baltimore Sun| accessdate =June 18, 2010| date = March 23, 2002| url = http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2002-03-23/features/0203230044_1_mckeldin-library-nose-university-of-maryland}} In 1992 a duplicate statue was placed at Maryland Stadium, where the football team touch it for good luck as they pass by before games. Additional Testudo statues now sit outside of the Gossett Team House near the stadium; [[XFINITY Center (College Park, Maryland)|XFINITY Center]], the school's basketball arena; the Riggs Alumni Center; and in the lobby of the [[Adele H. Stamp Student Union]]. In 1994, the [[Maryland General Assembly]] approved legislation to name the diamondback terrapin (''malaclemys terrapin terrapin'') as the official state reptile and the legally codified mascot of the University of Maryland.{{cite web| last = Maryland State Archives| title = Diamondback Terrapin, Maryland State Reptile| accessdate =June 18, 2010 | date = March 8, 2010| url = http://www.mdgovpap.net/msa/mdmanual/01glance/symbols/html/reptile.html}} Beginning in the 2000s, the university promoted the slogan, "Fear the Turtle" as a rallying cry for school pride.{{cite web|title=Fear the Turtle! University of Maryland|publisher=University of Maryland|url=http://www.feartheturtle.umd.edu/about/ |accessdate=February 8, 2008 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070809225009/http://www.feartheturtle.umd.edu/about/ | archivedate = August 9, 2007}} The most popular Testudo statue lies in front of the McKeldin Library. The statue's nose is polished by passers-by that have rubbed it for good luck. Around finals week, students start giving offerings to Testudo in the hope of good grades. At that time, one can find Testudo weighted down with anything from trash to TVs to couches, all of which disappears by the next morning (with the help of cleaning staff). Some of the most unusual offerings have included a door, a light pole, a car, and a lighted Christmas tree. In fall 2013, the Testudo statue caught fire because of an ill-advised mixture of offerings and a lit candle. Local news channels reported about this event and it trended on [[Twitter]].{{cite web |url=http://www.wjla.com/articles/2013/12/maryland-testudo-statue-fire-likely-not-intentional-authorities-say-98270.html|title=Maryland Testudo statue fire ruled accidental |work=WJLA |accessdate=May 29, 2015}} ==Notable alumni== {{refimprove section|date=September 2014}} [[File:UMD Riggs Alumni fountain.JPG|thumb|Kappa Kappa Gamma Memorial Fountain in front of the Riggs Alumni Center]] {{main article|List of University of Maryland, College Park people|President of the University of Maryland, College Park}} Notable alumni include [[Party leaders of the United States House of Representatives|House Minority Whip]] [[Steny Hoyer]]; [[Google]] co-founder [[Sergey Brin]]; [[The Muppets]] creator [[Jim Henson]]; ''The Wire'' creator [[David Simon]], and [[Seinfeld]] co-creator [[Larry David]]. Prominent alumni in business include [[Ed Snider]], Chairman of [[Comcast Spectacor]] and owner of the [[Philadelphia Flyers]]; [[Jim Walton (journalist)]], President and CEO of [[CNN]]; [[Kevin Plank]], founder of the athletic apparel company [[Under Armour]]; Leonard Kevin "Len" Bias was a first team All-American college basketball forward; [[Chris Kubasik]], former President of [[Lockheed Martin]]; [[Carly Fiorina]], former CEO of [[Hewlett-Packard]]; [http://encyclopedia.jrank.org/articles/pages/3973/Kerger-Paula-A.html Paula Kerger], President and CEO of the Public Broadcasting System (PBS); Telecommunications entrepreneur [[Brian Hinman]], Hamad Al Sayari, Former governor of the Saudi Arabian Central Bank (Saudi Arabia Monetary Agency); and Hugo Santana CEO of IBM Mexico.{{cite web|title=On Cloud Nine|url=https://www.thebusinessyear.com/mexico-2013/on-cloud-nine/vip-interview|website=The Business Year|publisher=The Business Year|accessdate=December 2012}}{{citation needed|date=September 2014}} [[File:UMD Arch gateway.JPG|thumb|left|upright|An arched gateway on campus]] Television personality [[Connie Chung]]; [[E!]] News reporter [[Giuliana Rancic]] graduated with a bachelor's degree from the [[Philip Merrill College of Journalism]]. [[ESPN]] reporters [[Bonnie Bernstein]] and [[Tim Kurkjian]] graduated from the [[Philip Merrill College of Journalism]]. [[Scott Van Pelt]], also of ESPN, attended the Phillip Merrill College of Journalism, but finished a few credits short of graduation. Journalist [[Carl Bernstein]], who won the [[Pulitzer Prize for Public Service]] for his coverage of the [[Watergate scandal]], attended the university but did not graduate. [[Mark Rosenker]], Former Chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) and now CBS NEWS Transportation Safety Analyst graduated with a Bachelor of Arts in radio and television. [[Kiran Chetry]], co-host of CNN's ''[[American Morning]]'', graduated with a Bachelor of Arts in broadcast journalism. [[Heidi Collins]] of ''[[CNN Newsroom]]'' graduated with a Bachelor of science. Former Maryland governor [[Harry R. Hughes]] also attended. [[Gayle King]], editor-at-large for ''[[O, The Oprah Magazine]]'', graduated from Maryland with a degree in psychology. Television show host Bruce DePuyt, host of News Talk on [[NewsChannel 8 (cable channel)|NewsChannel8]] graduated from Phillip Merrill College of Journalism. Attendees within the fields of science and mathematics are: Nobel Laureates [[Raymond Davis Jr.]], 2002 winner in Physics; [[Herbert Hauptman]], 1985 winner in Chemistry, and [[Fields Medal]] winner [[Charles Fefferman]]. Other alumni include [[George Dantzig]], considered the father of linear programming; late [[NASA]] [[astronaut]] [[Judith Resnik]], who died in the destruction of the [[Space Shuttle Challenger]] during the launch of mission [[STS-51-L]]; engineer [[James S. Albus]], founder of a division at the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST); and [[NASA]] Administrator [[Michael D. Griffin]]. Several donors have distinguished themselves for their sizable gifts to the university. Businessman [[Robert Smith (philanthropist)|Robert H. Smith]], who graduated from the university in 1950 with a degree in accounting, has given over $45 million to the business school that now bears his name, and to the Clarice Smith Performing Arts Center, which bears his wife's name.[http://www.rhsmith.umd.edu/news/stories/2005/smithgift.html Robert H. Smith School of Business to Share in University of Maryland Gifts Totaling $60 Million] {{wayback|url=http://www.rhsmith.umd.edu/news/stories/2005/smithgift.html |date=20060908084925 }} Construction entrepreneur [[A. James Clark]], who graduated with an engineering degree in 1950, has also donated over $45 million to the college of engineering, which also bears his name. Another engineering donor, [[Jeong H. Kim]], earned his PhD from the university in 1991 and gave $5 million for the construction of a state-of-the-art engineering building.{{Cite news |issn=0740-5421 |last=Pearlstein |first=Steven |title=Steven Pearlstein – Economic Recycling Enlarges U-Md.'s Engineering School |work=The Washington Post |accessdate=June 18, 2010|date=September 21, 2005 |url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/09/20/AR2005092001828.html}} [[Philip Merrill]], a media figure, donated $10 million to the College of Journalism.{{cite news |last=Fisher |first=Marc |title=Phil Merrill and the Vanishing Iconoclastic Publishers |work=Raw Fisher |accessdate=June 18, 2010 |date=June 13, 2006 |url=http://blog.washingtonpost.com/rawfisher/2006/06/phil_merrill_and_the_vanishing.html}} [[Robert E. Fischell]], physicist, inventor, and holder of more than 200 U.S. and foreign medical patents[http://web.mit.edu/invent/iow/fischell.html MIT Inventor of the Week Archives.] Accessed February 22, 2007.[http://www.nationalhealthmuseum.org/news/articles/newest_trustees.html "NHM Board Welcomes Renowned Health and Medical Figures as Newest Trustees,"] National Health Museum News, Accessed February 22, 2007.[http://www.devicelink.com/mddi/archive/04/08/039.html "Industry Pioneer – Robert Fischell,"] Medical Device & Diagnostic Industry – August 2004. Accessed February 22, 2007. donated $30 million to the [[A. James Clark School of Engineering]],{{cite news|last=Fischell |first=Robert |title=New Bioengineering Dept. Established by Gift of $30 Million from Renowned Biomedical Inventor |publisher=UMD Newsdesk |accessdate=September 27, 2012 |date=December 19, 2005 |url=http://www.newsdesk.umd.edu/archive/release.cfm?year=2005&ArticleID=1193}} establishing the Fischell Department of Bioengineering. In addition, the university has a number of executive [[trustee]]s which are elected and have professional backgrounds.[https://advancement.umd.edu/foundation/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=55&Itemid=54 Board of Trustees].
